Admiral William J.ohn Flanagan, Jr. (born March 27, 1943) is a retired United States Navy four star admiral who served as Commander in Chief, U.S. Atlantic Fleet (CINCLANTFLT) from 1994 to 1996.[1][2]

William John Flanagan, Jr. was born in 1943[3]

In addition to his bachelor's degree in Marine Transportation, Flanagan received a Master's degree in Political Science from the American University and earned a degree from Harvard Business School.[4]

Career

The younger Flanagan graduated from the Massachusetts Maritime Academy in 1964 with a Bachelor of Science degree in Marine Transportation, joining the Merchant Marine and working for American Export-Isbrandtsen Lines out of New York, where he achieved the grade of Second Mate. After three years of service with American Export Lines, Flanagan accepted a full commission with the U.S. Navy in 1967.

On June 27, 1981, Flanagan reported to commissioning crew of USS Kidd (DDG-993) as her first Commanding Officer. He had now advanced to the rank of Captain. Flannagan commanded the guided missile destroyer—the lead ship of her class—on her first deployment to the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean.

On October 5, 1994, Flanagan was promoted to the rank of Admiral and was assigned as Commander in Chief of the Atlantic Fleet (CINCLANTFLT). At the end of his tenure in this position, he was responsible for more than 200,000 Navy and Marine Corps personnel, 220 vessels, 1,500 aircraft, and 27 shore installations. Admiral Flanagan stepped down from commanding the Atlantic Fleet on December 20, 1996, and retired shortly thereafter after approximately thirty years of naval service. [5] [6]

Flanagan, William (Jr.), American composer and music critic; b. Detroit, Aug. 14, 1923; d. of an overdose of barbituates in N.Y., Aug. 31, 1969. He studied composition at the Eastman School of Music in Rochester, N.Y., with Phillips and Rogers; then at the Berkshire Music Center in Tanglewood with Honegger, Berger, and Copland; also, in N.Y., with Diamond. William H. Flanagan, Jr., a resident of Needham, Massachusetts for 52-years, died peacefully on August 21, 2022.

William H Flanagan Jr

Bill was born in Boston, MA, on August 22, 1931, to William H. Flanagan, Sr. and Catherine (Lynch) Flanagan. Growing up in South Boston and then Milton, MA, he attended St. Sebastian’s High School (class of ’49), and Boston College (’53).

Bill met his loving wife Clare Lyons in 1948. They married in 1955 and celebrated their 67th anniversary this past April.

After tending bar in South Boston during the 1950’s, Bill began his career in the insurance industry with John Hancock in 1961, then with Allstate in 1963. In 1988, he founded Flanagan Insurance Agency, Inc. in Lexington, MA. Bill was also a proud co-founder of the allMass Group, a local network of insurance agencies.

Bill was the devoted father of Kay Martland and her husband Ted of Nashua, NH; Carol Healey and her husband Tony of Needham; William Joseph Flanagan and his wife Christine of Walpole; Ann Marie Rogers and her husband Chris of Shrewsbury; Susan Cosolito and her husband Frank of Medfield; Edward Flanagan and his wife Sarah of Arlington; and Richard Flanagan and his wife Leslie of Braintree. Bill is also survived by 18 grandchildren and 8 great grandchildren, all of whom he adored. Bill was predeceased by his sisters Anne Thompson and Joan Cochran, his brother Jack Flanagan, his daughter Mary Flanagan, and his grandson Jake Rogers.

A proud member of the Knights of Columbus and St. Joseph’s Church in Needham, Bill’s life was one of faith and service. He was a talented poet, raconteur, and had a joke for any occasion.

To send your condolences, please continue to the GF Doherty & Sons Funeral Home website here.

William Flanagan Jr., 88 or 89 years old, died Thursday, Aug. 20. The former Darien resident had served eight years on the Planning & Zoning Commission, four years on the Monuments and Ceremonies Commission and a year on the Representative Town Meeting.

An obituary from Spadaccino and Leo P. Gallagher & Son Community Funeral Home:

William “Bill” K. Flanagan Jr. was born and raised in South Orange, N.J. in 1926. He graduated from Columbia High School in Maplewood, N.J., in 1944.

Prior to graduating from high school, he enlisted in the U.S. Navy, and was assigned to the 144th Naval Construction Battalion Advance Base Construction Depot in Guam. He attended Navy officer training at the Univ. of Mississippi and was honorably discharged in June 1945.

In 1949, Bill received a B.A degree in history from Brown University, and in 1952, a J.D, degree in law from Rutgers Law School. He was a member of the bar in New Jersey and New York. He started his legal career as a litigator in his father’s firm in Newark, N.J., where he completed many jury trials.

He then went to ITT Corporation where he worked for 30 years as an international corporate transaction attorney. He retired from ITT in 1987 as a senior legal officer of the company. For several years thereafter, Bill was an attorney for Walsh Construction Company, in Trumbull, CT.

Bill served the Town of Darien for more than 12 years: 1 year on the RTM, 8 years on the Planning and Zoning Commission and 4 years on the Monuments and Ceremonies Commission.

He was a member of the Darien Senior Men’s Association (president in 2000-01), and of the Senior Songsters and sang with several church choirs.

His wife for over 30 years, Lynn DeCesare, died in 1990. He later married Anne La Ferte Meyjes, who died in 2014. His sister, Patricia Kiernan, and his brother, Philbin Flanagan, predeceased him. He is survived by his brother, Bruce Flanagan, and four children, William Flanagan III, Suzanne Wright, Tara Flanagan, and Nina Flanagan, and five grandchildren.

There are no calling hours. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, Aug. 25 at 10:30 a.m. at St. Thomas More Church in Darien, CT. Online condolences may be made by visiting the funeral home website.

William J. Larkin, Jr., a native of Troy, New York, graduated from LaSalle Institute in Troy, and attended the University of Maryland and the University of Denver. In the United States Army, he served in many key positions, both in the United States and overseas, and saw combat during World War II in the Philippines operation, and during the Korean War.

After 23 years of service, Bill Larkin retired from the Army in 1967 with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He was the recipient of the Legion of Merit and seven Army Commendation Medals, and was awarded one Battle Star for the Philippines and six Battle Stars for the Korean War. After his military service, Senator Larkin served as an Executive Assistant in the New York State Senate, and from 1976-1977 was Supervisor of the Town of New Windsor in Orange County, New York.

Senator Larkin is the former Chairman of the Senate Veterans Committee. As Chairman, he sponsored some of the most sweeping changes in veterans’ benefits laws in 30 years. The new laws increased financial protections for families of U.S. service members. Most recently, Senator Larkin sponsored the Veterans’ Equality Act, which was signed into law by Governor Cuomo just last year. He continues to serve on the Senate’s Veterans, Homeland Security and Military Affairs Committee where he has sponsored numerous laws to assist veterans.

Senator Larkin has led two national campaigns to ensure that our nation does not forget the servicemen and women who have been awarded the Purple Heart Medal for being killed or wounded in combat. His efforts resulted in the United States Postal Service’s first issuance of a Purple Heart postage stamp in 2003. The stamp continues to be circulated today.

Senator Larkin also spearheaded the establishment of the Purple Heart Hall of Honor. The Hall collects and preserves the stories of over 100,000 Purple Heart recipients from all branches of service, and includes educational exhibits related to military history and the Purple Heart, which dates back to George Washington.

In 2014, the United States Army presented Senator Larkin with its highest civilian award, the Decoration for Distinguished Civilian Service, in recognition of his decades of service on behalf of veterans. The Certificate from the Department of the Army recognizes Senator Larkin for his extraordinary contributions to the well-being of soldiers, veterans, Army civilians and their families. His support has helped the Army improve its capabilities, readiness and quality of life for them.

Senator Larkin is a member of the Knights of Columbus, Veterans of Foreign Wars, the American Legion and the Disabled American Veterans, and is an honorary member of the West Point Society of New York. He is married to Patricia Kurucz McGuirk Larkin, and between them, they have eight children and 17 grandchildren.

Senator Larkin’s continuing commitment and outstanding service to our soldiers, veterans and their families reflects greatly upon him, the State of New York and the United States of America.

Bud Flanagan isn’t all business. He just sounds that way.

As he should. Adm. William J. Flanagan Jr. is commander-in-chief of Atlantic Fleet, one of the Navy’s two largest commands. From his headquarters at the sprawling Norfolk Naval Base, he controls the destiny of 17 naval bases, 208 ships, 1,300 aircraft, 131,000 officers and sailors, and a $10 billion annual budget. His corporate equivalent would be the chief executive officer of the 130th-ranked Fortune 500 company.

The parallels don’t stop with the figures; Flanagan brings a distinctly businesslike approach to the command. At times, he sounds more like a CEO than a senior naval officer.

“I want to be able to give the American public a better product for less money in the future,” Flanagan says. “I want us to become as efficient as we can. I want us to protect the investment that the generous American taxpayers have put in our hands.”

Flanagan has plenty of commander in him, too – as well as a strict sense of right and wrong that grew naturally from his father, a lifelong policeman, and strong Roman Catholic roots. When he learned in October 1995 that the Navy had kept a 95-year-old York County woman from selling a parcel of property crossed by ancient, unused Navy railroad tracks, Flanagan wasted no words.

His response: “Fix it today.” It was.

Flanagan, 53, looks both parts. Silver-haired, barrel-chested and sharp-eyed, he displays, despite a slight uneasiness at the interview process, a confident, commanding presence. Although he enjoys the trappings of his four-star position, friends say he’s no martinet. In fact, they say, he is a gregarious and highly social man.

“I think he’s much easier going and more down-to-earth than most flag officers,” said retired Rear Adm. Maurice Bresnahan, an old school chum.

Those qualities are reflected in his leadership style. Whether commanding a fleet, a ship, or overseeing the Navy’s dealings with Congress, Flanagan “believes in the family concept,” said Capt. Don Nash, twice a Flanagan associate and now top assistant to the deputy commander of U.S. Atlantic Command. Flanagan, Nash said, empowers people to do their jobs while encouraging them to work as a team. “He inspires people to do more than they think they can do,” he said.

“Nobody doubts who the boss is, but nobody feels that they are subservient to him,” Nash said.

While Flanagan may look the part, his “company” most assuredly does not. Unlike some CEOs, Flanagan doesn’t produce a tangible product for market. He turns out combat-ready aircraft carrier battle groups.

Flanagan has six of these. Although the ships and crews already exist, they must be maintained, trained and ready to deploy every six months on a rotating basis.

American taxpayers incur an enormous expense for the services provided by Flanagan’s organization. Each carrier group’s 18-month cycle of preparation and deployment costs $500 million.

In addition to this huge expense, Flanagan must do as much as his predecessors with less; post-Cold War reductions have shrunk his fleet, but the Navy’s deployment schedule hasn’t changed. Those realities make Flanagan look hard at shaving costs and making his vast operation more efficient.

Flanagan, a Harvard Business School graduate, has a strong affinity for concepts such as efficiency. “My view is that there’s a lot of principles involved in the business world that we need to employ,” he says.

Efficiency is spelled two ways for Flanagan. One is at it is applied to the art of warfighting, practiced at its highest level.

“If we’re going to bring this force somewhere to employ it in anger, it’s got to be able to do so at a very, very high rate of efficiency, and bring all our people home,” Flanagan said. “That’s really the goal.”

The other efficiency is strictly monetary. The fleet’s $10 billion budget and increasing pressure to reduce federal spending demand that money be saved wherever possible.

But while fiscal thriftiness has a strong appeal for Flanagan, he says it also produces benefits for the operational commanders who receive his forces.

“The efficiencies that we’re able to realize will be passed on to these operational commanders in terms of force availability,” Flanagan says. “And I think that’s critical.”

To realize the savings, Flanagan said, the fleet is taking a fresh look at its accounting practices – the means it uses to calculate the “cost of goods sold.”

“We know now what those are,” he said. “We’re in the process of building a management accounting system to better account for what it is we spend and how it is we spend it.

“I think those are two very key things.”

Flanagan is also saving money through more efficient management of his floating assets. His ships, unless laid up for extended maintenance, must spend six months of each 18-month cycle on overseas deployments to the Mediterranean. But Atlantic Fleet ships also patrol the Caribbean Sea and points further south, and conduct joint operations with allies in that region.

Flanagan, who was 2nd Fleet commander prior to assuming the top job at Atlantic Fleet, realized that about 25 percent of his available forces were at any given time required to be at sea for Caribbean duty. So, he reasoned, “why don’t we build a force that operates exclusively in this region?”

By doing so, Flanagan said, the operators of those ships would become experts on the regional mission instead of spending additional time being trained for every possible contingency the Atlantic Fleet could face, the standard for ships preparing for Med cruises.

The result of that sort of thinking was the formation of the Western Hemisphere Group, a group of selected ships based in Mayport, Fla., that operates solely in Caribbean and South Atlantic waters.

“I think that we improved the product, and I think that we did it at less cost,” Flanagan said.

In addition, Flanagan, along with his Pacific Fleet counterpart, Adm. Ronald J. Zlatoper, has created a fleetwide, money-saving training schedule for ships preparing to go overseas. By keeping his ships near the U.S. coast instead of sailing to the Caribbean for the third and final phase of their training, Flanagan shaves 3,000 miles off each ship’s round trip and cuts the time spent doing such training in half.

Flanagan and Zlatoper have also combined efforts to streamline the two organizations’ training and operational procedures. Over the years, the two fleets, one based in Norfolk, the other in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, had developed into distinct and separate cultures – so much so that, according to Zlatoper aide Capt. Steve Clawson, ships from the two fleets meeting at sea could not, as recently as 15 years ago, effectively communicate or work together.

Now, that’s changing. “We decided that we would work together,” Zlatoper said recently. “Our predecessors started working to coordinate the two fleets, and we’ve continued that.”

Zlatoper gives Flanagan much of the credit for making the project a success. “From my estimation, he has really brought the flag officers of the surface fleet together better than anyone in my memory,” Zlatoper said.

Flanagan could also gain future savings for his fleet by way of a previously proposed project that, although it remains in the planning stages, could have significant impact on Hampton Roads.

Flanagan wants to combine public and private transportation assets to make the region a highly effective launching pad for massive numbers of troops en route to an overseas crisis. This “intermodal transportation system” would combine highway, rail, and port operations in a manner that would serve both military and commercial needs more efficiently.

In one example of cost-sharing, Flanagan would provide easements to Norfolk Naval Base property to allow the adjacent Norfolk International Terminal to expand its commercial operations. At the same time, NIT would take on the Navy’s cargo-handling operation, saving tax dollars.

“The way I’m looking at it is, how can we do something that’ll benefit the military, and as a result benefit the United States, in terms of being able to mobilize if we have to with the greatest efficiency … at the same time, how can all of this benefit the community?” Flanagan said.

This sort of thinking is what has attracted the attention of the region’s business, civic and government leaders, who have included Flanagan on the organizing committee for the Hampton Roads Public/Private Partnership, a new group being organized in hopes of improving regional cooperation on economic issues. Flanagan says that given the Navy’s size here, that’s as it should be.

“The Navy puts about $11 billion a year in this economy,” he said. “That’s a significant contribution, and it makes us the largest contributor of anyone in this region.”

Despite his drive to maximize potential and efficiency, Flanagan takes the time to listen.

He says he believes in a workplace where honest dissent from the party line can be expressed without fear of retribution. His leadership style is deliberate, and stems from a sense of purpose that others say Flanagan possessed even as a young man.

“He was always focused,” said Neil Nightingale, chief of police in the Cape Cod town of Barnstable, where Flanagan grew up. “He always knew where he wanted to go.” Nightingale worked for Flanagan’s father, the former deputy chief, from whom the son inherited the nickname “Bud.”

Nightingale remembers the younger Flanagan as “always well-behaved and polite. He was not a rowdy … he was always a straight arrow.”

“I knew he was destined for big things,” said George Gillis, a friend and classmate of Flanagan’s at the Massachusetts Maritime Academy in nearby Buzzard’s Bay. “He was so personable, so disciplined, so dedicated. When he wanted something, he got it.”

Flanagan spent some of his youthful summers caddying at a golf club frequented by the Kennedy clan. But in addition to walking the greens, he, like many other Cape Cod youths, worked on lobster and fishing boats. Both of his grandfathers were sea captains. Life at sea intrigued him.

At the maritime academy, Flanagan lived on a ship; dormitories weren’t then an option. “We did every single job a sailor does on a ship,” said Bresnahan, now the assistant to the academy president. “That stood me in good stead, and I’m sure it did Bud Flanagan.”

The course work didn’t come easy. “We had a tough regimen here, and he struggled like the rest of us,” Bresnahan said. “Academically. It’s a tough school. It didn’t come easy.”

In 1964, Flanagan graduated and set forth, armed with a degree in marine transportation and a 3rd Class Coast Guard license. While some of his classmates began their Navy careers, Flanagan chose to follow in the footsteps of his grandfathers and join the U.S. Merchant Marine. He served three years, sailing with American Export-Isbrandtsen Lines out of New York.

Meanwhile, U.S. involvement in Vietnam had grown from an advisory role to full-blown war. In 1967, Flanagan accepted a full Naval commission and sailed west. He served on two ships during that war, and hasn’t looked back to civilian life.

Flanagan was selected to be the 1973-74 Chief of Naval Operations Fellow, serving under Admirals Elmo R. Zumwalt and James L. Holloway III. In 1975, he commanded his first ship, USS Bronstein. In 1979, at age 35, he was named one of the U.S. Jaycees’ Ten Outstanding Young Americans – along with Vietnam War hero and Pittsburgh Steelers running back “Rocky” Bleier, and Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton.

The following year, he began a three-year hitch as the first commander of the USS Kidd, a new class of guided missile destroyer. In 1988 – his 19th year of service – Flanagan was selected for promotion to rear admiral. He subsequently served as commander of Destroyer Squadron Five in San Diego and of the Norfolk-based Second Fleet. In October 1994, he assumed his present command, and donned his fourth star.

Flanagan’s meteoric rise through the ranks makes some think he’s a logical candidate to rise even higher in the U.S. military hierarchy. But Flanagan downplays such possibilities, refuses to speculate on the future, and says he’s focused on his present work.

“I didn’t come here to use this as a springboard to some other opportunity,” Flanagan says he has repeatedly told his staff, “but rather, just to make sure that we got this done as well as we could.”

THE FLANAGAN LEADERSHIP PHILOSOPHY

1. Add wisdom from the top down. “In other words, if you know something, and obviously you do, because you’re in a senior position, then you’ve got to share that with your subordinates. When it comes time for them to take your position, they’ll do it not as well, but better than you.”

2. Take fear out of the workplace. “It’s not a sin to make a mistake. We learn from them. It’s an attitude that if we approach this with openness, and goodwill, and moral purpose, we’ll get improvement.”

3. You’ve got to have optimism. “The fleet’s as big as the fleet is right now. It’s the best fleet we’ve got. I’ve never heard a man win a fight that went into it thinking he was going to lose. I don’t think we’re going to lose anything, and we all need to think that way. We have a new Navy that’s restructured, and that’s important to have confidence in, and to build on.”

ADM. WILLIAM J. FLANAGAN JR.

Age: 53

Occupation: Commander of the U.S. Navy Atlantic Fleet

Home: The Missouri House, Norfolk Naval Base

Family: Married to the former Barbara Ann Brendes. he has three daughters: Margaret, 18, Elizabeth, 22, and Kathryn, 23

Education: Bachelor’s degree in maritime transportation, Massachusetts Maritime Academy; Master’s degree in political science, American University; graduate, Harvard Business School

Awards: Defense Distringuished Service Medal; Legion of Merit (4); Meritorious Service Medal with Gold Star; Navy Commendation Medal (2); Combat Action Ribbon; Meritorious Service Ribbon

Admiral William John Flanagan Jr. (born March 27, 1943) is a retired United States Navy four star admiral who served as Commander in Chief, United States Atlantic Fleet from 1994 to 1996.

Early life and education

Flanagan was born in 1943. In addition to his bachelor's degree in marine transportation, Flanagan received a master's degree in political science from the American University and earned a degree from Harvard Business School.

Naval career

Flanagan graduated from the Massachusetts Maritime Academy in 1964 with a Bachelor of Science degree in marine transportation, joining the Merchant Marine and working for American Export-Isbrandtsen Lines out of New York, where he achieved the grade of second mate. After three years of service with American Export Lines, Flanagan accepted a commission with the United States Navy in 1967.

On June 27, 1981, Flanagan reported to commissioning crew of USS Kidd (DDG-993) as the ship's first commanding officer. He had now advanced to the rank of captain. Flannagan commanded the guided missile destroyer—the lead ship of her class—on her first deployment to the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean.

On October 5, 1994, Flanagan was promoted to the rank of admiral and was assigned as Commander in Chief of the Atlantic Fleet. At the end of his tenure in this position, he was responsible for more than 200,000 Navy and Marine Corps personnel, 220 vessels, 1,500 aircraft, and 27 shore installations. Flanagan stepped down from commanding the Atlantic Fleet on December 20, 1996, and retired shortly thereafter after approximately thirty years of naval service.

Salaries

In determining median salaries, jobs classified as “JD advantage” have been excluded (i.e., positions in which the employer requires a JD or considers it an advantage to hold such a degree, but in which admission to the bar is not required).

A Juris Doctor degree, or a J.D., is an academic credential that paves the way for a career as a lawyer.

"A J.D. is the foundational law degree that an American attorney obtains before taking the bar exam and being sworn in as an attorney," wrote Hannah Carroll-Altman, a criminal defense lawyer with the Berry Law Firm in Nebraska, in an email. "Its purpose is to broadly prepare an attorney to practice law."

Carroll-Altman, who has both a J.D. and a master of laws degree, commonly known as an LL.M., says one key distinction between a J.D. and an LL.M. is that an LL.M. is "a highly specialized advanced law degree," which someone can only pursue after he or she has already graduated from law school. An LL.M. typically focuses on a particular area of law, she says, while a J.D. offers an overview of multiple areas of law.

What You Can Expect to Learn From a J.D. Program

According to law school experts, courses on the following topics are often mandatory for J.D. students:

J.D. students at law schools that are accredited by the American Bar Association must also participate in a legal writing course, a professional responsibility course, plus an experiential learning course, such as a simulation class, a law clinic or a field placement.

Onnig Dombalagian, the vice dean for academic affairs at Tulane University Law School in New Orleans, says a solid J.D. program shows aspiring attorneys how to advocate on behalf of clients "zealously and effectively," without compromising ethics. "An effective J.D. program not only teaches students legal doctrine, but also prepares them for practice by teaching them how to identify and address legal problems," he adds.

Andrew Strauss, the dean of the University of Dayton School of Law in Ohio, describes a J.D. degree as an "advanced liberal arts degree" that can be used in a variety of ways professionally. "It actually applies liberal arts thinking to concrete problems in the real world," he says. "I often think of what we do as lawyers as right at the juncture of theory and practice." He says lawyers are experts at envisioning ways of implementing ideas and turning them into realities. So one of the skills J.D. students gain from law school is the ability to imagine how legal principles might apply to complex issues, such as figuring out who should be held legally responsible for the harm caused by an accident, Strauss adds.

Strauss says that, in order to decipher the meaning of a legal text, it helps to understand the rationale behind the law. Because lawyers on opposing sides of a legal dispute will often debate over lawmakers' intentions, J.D. students are taught how to deliver compelling legal arguments about the proper interpretation of the law, he adds.

Can You Become an Attorney Without a J.D. Degree?

Though becoming a licensed attorney without earning a J.D. is feasible under certain circumstances in the U.S., it is rare for someone to accomplish this, legal experts say. There are some states, such as California, Vermont, Virginia and Washington, which allow people to take the state bar exam without having attended law school if they have completed a legal apprenticeship. However, most U.S. states require that people attend law school before sitting for the bar exam.

And though most states allow graduates of law schools outside the U.S. to take state bar exams under certain conditions, international law school grads are often required to deal with hurdles that their U.S.-educated counterparts are not obligated to face. For instance, in many states, lawyers educated outside the U.S. must demonstrate that their education was functionally equivalent to a U.S. J.D. program and that it included training in common law principles. These lawyers often must take law courses at an accredited U.S. law school in order to gain eligibility to take a state bar exam.

Strauss cautions that preparing for a state bar exam via an apprenticeship as opposed to attending a formal law school might be challenging, and he warns that some legal employers may be reluctant to hire somebody without a formal law degree.

However, Marc J. Randazza, a First Amendment and intellectual property attorney who is a managing partner and founder with the Randazza Legal Group, says he would be impressed with a candidate who had "read the law," meaning that he or she had received their legal training via an apprenticeship as opposed to a J.D. program. "That shows tenacity, that shows intelligence, that shows creative thinking and that shows somebody with the sense to not waste $150,000 for a ticket that they can get punched by actually working for four years," says Randazza, who has both a J.D. and an LL.M. Randazza also notes that tuition and fees at non-U.S. law schools are often lower than those at U.S. law schools, so students at international law schools may pay less for a legal education than their peers at U.S. law schools.

How to Decide Whether to Get a J.D. Degree

J.D. programs typically last for three years, and the financial cost of attending these programs can be significant, practicing attorneys warn. So it's important for anyone who is contemplating a J.D. degree to do a cost-benefit analysis to gauge whether pursuing a J.D. is the best choice, attorneys say.

Israel F. Piedra, a civil litigation attorney with the Welts, White & Fontaine law firm in New Hampshire who is also a member of the New Hampshire House of Representatives, says it's important for prospective law students to consider if they have a compelling reason to pursue a law degree. Law school hopefuls should factor in whether legal training is either necessary or beneficial for their dream career, he says.

"I think a good part of that equation is (asking): What are my chances of getting a good job – a good, well-paying job – after graduating from this law school?" he says.

Randazza warns that taking on a significant amount of debt in order to attend law school might put an aspiring attorney in a situation where, after law school, he or she must pursue a high-paying job, as opposed to whatever job he or she finds most interesting and fulfilling. "Find the school from which you will graduate with the least debt, because that debt is a shackle on your ability to do a job you like rather than a job you need in order to pay off your loans," he says.

How Hard Is Law school?

Piedra cautions that law school can be extraordinarily demanding. "It's not easy to coast along," he says. "You need to stay on top of your reading. It's a lot of reading."

He says memorizing and regurgitating facts is not sufficient for success in law school classes, which require students to understand how to apply legal principles to a wide array of circumstances.

Criminal defense attorney Patrick Barone, founder of Barone Defense firm in Michigan, notes that the first year of law school tends to be the most challenging. "Many students drop out the first year because the work and reading load is so high, as is the stress and the competition among students," Barone wrote in an email. "In the first year, students are asked to stand and recite a case from the reading assigned, giving the issue, analysis, rule and conclusion of the case. Students are randomly selected each class for this recitation, and it can be very anxiety producing."

However, Randazza says aspiring lawyers should not be scared of law school. He says "the myth that it is difficult" is an idea that lawyers often express when they are touting the value of their services. "So I would tell any prospective student, 'Do not be afraid.'" Randazza, who earned his J.D. from Georgetown University, suggests that getting into a highly selective law school may be more challenging than completing the coursework and graduating from that type of school.

Strauss says law school is rigorous, but not so overwhelming that prospective law students should feel intimidated. "It's hard, it's a challenge, but it's not essentially different in nature than any other new challenge. ... You're teaching yourself to think in a different kind of way," he says.

Strauss says learning the law is analogous to learning a foreign language, because the law operates according to certain rules, just like a language does. And he says learning the law is also similar to learning how to ski, because at the beginning of the learning process, students often struggle to gain their footing and feel grounded. He adds that aspiring lawyers are often so anxious about the difficulty of law school that it is counterproductive. "That can be really self-defeating," he says. "It's just something to learn."

Admiral William J. “Bud” Flanagan Jr., the business-minded commander of Norfolk’s Atlantic Fleet, has announced his retirement, command officials said Wednesday.

The retirement of Flanagan, 53, must be formally approved by the U.S. Senate. He’ll be relieved Dec. 13 as Fleet commander by Adm. J. Paul Reason, former commander of the fleet’s Surface Force.

The silver-haired Flanagan, who skyrocketed to the rank of rear admiral in his 19th year in the Navy, became renowned in Navy circles for his aggressive application of business principles to the military world. A Harvard Business School graduate, Flanagan devoted much of the past two years to streamlining and more efficiently managing his $10 billion operation, headquartered at Norfolk Naval Base, and to efforts to privatize various operations at Norfolk and the command’s other major bases.

“I want to be able to give the American public a better product for less money in the future,” Flanagan told the Daily Press during an April interview. “I want us to become as efficient as we can.”

Twice considered for the chief of naval operations job, Flanagan, a 29-year veteran, leaves the Navy at a time when that post and other major Navy leadership positions are filled. And with selection of an eventual successor to U.S. Atlantic Command’s Gen. John J. Sheehan still a year away – and with two years served as Fleet commander, a typical tour length – Flanagan decided to step down, sources said.

Flanagan hasn’t announced his future plans, other than to relocate to the Eastern Shore with wife Barbara, a Fleet spokesman said.

Flanagan spent the past four years in the Norfolk area, the previous two at the helm of Atlantic Fleet and its 18 bases, 148,800 Navy and Marine Corps members, 195 ships and submarines, and nearly 1,360 aircraft. From June 1992 through July 1994, he commanded 2nd Fleet.

As Atlantic Fleet commander, Flanagan worked to achieve operational efficiencies in a variety of ways. He dedicated 25 percent of his fleet for duty in the Caribbean Sea and points south instead of constantly bringing in new ships and crews who required additional training for duty with the Western Hemisphere Group. He ordered the final portion of pre-deployment training for carrier battle groups to be conducted in U.S. waters instead of in the Caribbean, shaving 3,000 miles off each ship’s round trip.

Flanagan also initiated the development of a management accounting system “to better account for what it is we spend and how we spend it.”

In addition, Flanagan opened his bases to the public, removing the gate guards during the day, and literally opened Norfolk Naval Base for business. Outside firms are now bidding to develop parts of the base for ventures as varied as restaurants and parking garages to apartment complexes and a convention center.

Also on the table is a Flanagan proposal to transfer the Fleet’s cargo-handling operations to Norfolk International Terminal in exchange for granting NIT an easement to expand operations on land adjacent to the base. The proposal dovetails with the Pentagon’s desire to modernize the flow of troops and cargo through ports to overseas destinations using public-private ventures.

As a result of his efforts, local officials asked Flanagan to help organize the Hampton Roads Partnership, a business and civic group boosting improved regional cooperation on economic issues and in which Flanagan remains an active participant.

Born in Jessup, Ga., but raised in Cape Cod, Mass., Flanagan followed in the footsteps of his two seafaring grandfathers and joined the U.S. Merchant Marine after graduation from the Massachusetts Maritime Academy in 1964. Three years later, Flanagan accepted a full commission in the Navy and sailed off for the Vietnam War, where he served on two ships.

In addition to his two previous commands, Flanagan also served as the Navy’s Chief of Legislative Affairs in Washington and as commander of Destroyer Squadron Five, the destroyer USS Kidd and the frigate USS Bronstein.

Flanagan’s honors include selection as the 1973-74 Chief of Naval Operations Fellow, serving under Adms. Elmo R. Zumwalt and James L. Holloway III. In 1979, he was named, along with President Bill Clinton, as one of the U.S. Jaycees’ Ten Outstanding Young Americans. His awards include the Defense Distinguished Service Medal, four awards of the Legion of Merit and the Combat Action Ribbon.
